markdown: on the chemical make-up of the particular fat. If it is largely composed of polyunsaturated fatty acids it is called a polyunsaturated fat. Regardless of the composition of fat it contains 9 calories per gram and must be controlled to keep calories low. 5. **POLYUNSATURATED FATS,** which are recommended in the low fat plan, are usually liquid oils of vegetable origin. Oils such as corn, cottonseed, safflower, sesame seed, and sunflower seed are high in polyunsaturated fat. They tend to lower the level of cholesterol in the blood. Salad dressing, cooking fats and margarines should contain the recommended polyunsaturated vegetable oils for their cholesterol-lowering effect. 6. MONOUNSATURATED FATS: Fats that neither contribute to atherosclerosis nor help to prevent it. These are fats such as those found in olive oil and peanut oil. It may be used for flavor occasionally, but it should not take the place of polyunsaturated vegetable oils. 7. **HYDROGENATION** is a chemical process which lowers the amount of polyunsaturates in a vegetable oil and makes them more stable and hard at room temperature. These oils then resemble saturated fat. 8. **CHOLESTEROL** is a waxy material used in many of the body's chemical processes. Too much cholesterol in the blood encourages the development of heart and blood vessel disease. Cholesterol in the blood comes from two sources: it is manufactured by the body; and it is absorbed directly from foods of animal origin. Meat, fish and poultry contain cholesterol. Egg yolks and organ meats are very high in cholesterol. Such foods are limited in low fat diets. There is no cholesterol in foods of plant origin, such as fruits, vegetables, grains, cereal and nuts, and generous use of these foods is recommended. 9. **FAT CONTROLLED DIET:** A cholesterol-lowering diet, in which saturated fat is reduced, polyunsaturated fat is substituted for saturated fat, and total fat and cholesterol are moderately reduced. (It is referred to as a low fat, low cholesterol diet in the material.) 10. **ATHEROSCLEROSIS:** (Arteriosclerosis) A disease in which there is a thickening and narrowing of the arteries (major blood vessels). The deposit of fat, cholesterol and other materials in the inner layer of the arterial wall interferes with the normal blood flow and the nourishment of the tissues. Atherosclerosis is often called "hardening of the arteries" (arteriosclerosis) and is the basic cause of most heart attacks and strokes. 11. **CORONARY HEART DISEASE:** The most common form of adult heart disease in which the main arteries of the heart (the coronary arteries) have atherosclerotic deposits (see atherosclerosis) and the normal blood flow of the heart is impaired. 12. **TRIGLYCERIDES:** The major fatty substance found in foods from plant and animal sources. They are also manufactured by the body from all foods and beverages and deposited as fatty tissue. Fat circulates in the body mainly as triglycerides. <::logo: Creative Cuisine Creative Cuisine A stylized cooking pot or bowl with hearts and a spoon, rendered in an illustrative style.::> Source: https://www.industrydocuments.ucsf.edu/docs/symf0227

chunks.markdown: on the chemical make-up of the particular fat. If it is largely composed of polyunsaturated fatty acids it is called a polyunsaturated fat. Regardless of the composition of fat it contains 9 calories per gram and must be controlled to keep calories low.

5. **POLYUNSATURATED FATS,** which are recommended in the low fat plan, are usually liquid oils of vegetable origin. Oils such as corn, cottonseed, safflower, sesame seed, and sunflower seed are high in polyunsaturated fat. They tend to lower the level of cholesterol in the blood.
Salad dressing, cooking fats and margarines should contain the recommended polyunsaturated vegetable oils for their cholesterol-lowering effect.

6. MONOUNSATURATED FATS: Fats that neither contribute to atherosclerosis nor help to prevent it. These are fats such as those found in olive oil and peanut oil. It may be used for flavor occasionally, but it should not take the place of polyunsaturated vegetable oils.

7. **HYDROGENATION** is a chemical process which lowers the amount of polyunsaturates in a vegetable oil and makes them more stable and hard at room temperature. These oils then resemble saturated fat.
8. **CHOLESTEROL** is a waxy material used in many of the body's chemical processes. Too much cholesterol in the blood encourages the development of heart and blood vessel disease.
Cholesterol in the blood comes from two sources: it is manufactured by the body; and it is absorbed directly from foods of animal origin.

Meat, fish and poultry contain cholesterol. Egg yolks and organ meats are very high in cholesterol. Such foods are limited in low fat diets. There is no cholesterol in foods of plant origin, such as fruits, vegetables, grains, cereal and nuts, and generous use of these foods is recommended.

9. **FAT CONTROLLED DIET:** A cholesterol-lowering diet, in which saturated fat is reduced, polyunsaturated fat is substituted for saturated fat, and total fat and cholesterol are moderately reduced. (It is referred to as a low fat, low cholesterol diet in the material.) 10. **ATHEROSCLEROSIS:** (Arteriosclerosis) A disease in which there is a thickening and narrowing of the arteries (major blood vessels). The deposit of fat, cholesterol and other materials in the inner layer of the arterial wall interferes with the normal blood flow and the nourishment of the tissues. Atherosclerosis is often called "hardening of the arteries" (arteriosclerosis) and is the basic cause of most heart attacks and strokes.

11. **CORONARY HEART DISEASE:** The most common form of adult heart disease in which the main arteries of the heart (the coronary arteries) have atherosclerotic deposits (see atherosclerosis) and the normal blood flow of the heart is impaired. 12. **TRIGLYCERIDES:** The major fatty substance found in foods from plant and animal sources. They are also manufactured by the body from all foods and beverages and deposited as fatty tissue. Fat circulates in the body mainly as triglycerides.
<::logo: Creative Cuisine Creative Cuisine A stylized cooking pot or bowl with hearts and a spoon, rendered in an illustrative style.::>
